info: Aquila, the Eagle, was Zeus's bird. Aquila's most reknown task was to carry Ganymede to the heavens to serve as Zeus's cup bearer.
name: Aquila

info: Andromeda is the daughter of Cepheus and Cassiopeia of Ethiopia. Chained to a rock as a sacrifice to Cetus, she was saved by Perseus.
name: Andromeda

info: Sculptor was one of the most recent constellation named by Nicolas Louis de La Caille. It was originally named "The Sculptor's Workshop".
name: Sculptor

info: Ara is named after the altar of the centaur Chiron, the wisest creature on earth. Ara was also known as the altar Noah built after the great flood.
name: Ara

info: Libra, symbol of justice and balance, received its name when it was noticed that the Sun passes through it during the autumnal equinox.
name: Libra

info: Cetus was the sea monster sent by Neptune to devour Andromeda. Perseus defeated Cetus turning it into stone with the head of Medusa.
name: Cetus

info: In Greek mythology, the Aries represents the ram from which the golden fleece was obtained in the story of Jason and the Argonauts.
name: Aries

info: Scutum was invented by the Polish astronomer Hevelius in honour of the victory of the King of Poland Sobieskii against the Turks in 1683.
name: Scutum

info: Pyxis represents a mariner's compass. It used to be part of the constellation Argo Navis, before this was split into four smaller ones.
name: Pyxis

info: Bootes is the most ancient constellation in the sky. It eternally circles the Bears, Ursa Major and Ursa Minor, around the North Pole.
name: Bootes

info: Caelum, one of the constellations named by Nicolas Louis de La Caille, resembles a burin, which is an engravers tool similar to a chisel.
name: Caelum

info: Chamaeleon was named by Johann Bayer and it represents the color-changing lizard of the same name. It is hard to spot in northern latitudes.
name: Chamaeleon

info: Cancer, the Crab, was sent by Hera to distract Hercules fighting against Hydra, the multi-headed monster. Hercules crushed it with his foot.
name: Cancer

info: Capricornus is depicted as a goat with a fish tail, from the god Pan whose lower body turned into a fish, when he jumped into the river Nile.
name: Capricornus

info: This constellation was originally part of Argo Navis, the ship sailed by Jason and the Argonauts as they searched for the golden fleece.
name: Carina

info: Cassiopeia was the mother of Andromeda. Chained to her throne as punishment, she can be seen hanging upside down as she rotates.
name: Cassiopeia

info: Chiron was one of the Centaurs, beasts half-horse and half-human. Chiron was extremely wise and tutored Hercules and Jason.
name: Centaurus

info: Cepheus was the king of Ethiopia, husband of Cassiopeia and father of Andromeda, all of whom feature in the legend of Perseus.
name: Cepheus

info: This constellation refers to Berenice, the wife of Ptolemy III of Egypt, whose beautiful long hair was given to Aphrodite as a gift.
name: Coma Berenices

info: This constellations by Johannes Hevelius represents the dogs held on a leash by Bootes as he hunts for the bears Ursa Major and Ursa Minor.
name: Canes Venatici

info: The god Hephaestus, who was crippled as a child, was believed to have invented the chariot to allow his son to move him around more easily.
name: Auriga

info: This constellation represents the bird the Argonauts sent ahead to help them navigate the narrow passage at the mouth of the Black Sea.
name: Columba

info: This is another one of the southern constellations named by La Caille. It was named for its shape, which resembles a drawing compass.
name: Circinus

info: This represents the goblet of the god Apollo. It is the origin point of the Eta Craterids meteor shower, which occurs annually in mid-January.
name: Crater

info: This is an old constellation named by the astronomer Ptolemy, and it is believed to represent the crown worn by the centaur Sagittarius.
name: Corona Australis

info: It represents the crown created by the supreme goldsmith Hephaestus, and worn by Ariadne, the daughter of King Minos of Crete, at her wedding.
name: Corona Borealis

info: Apollo sent a crow to fetch water. It was condemned to endure eternal thirst for returning late, explaining why crows caw instead of singing.
name: Corvus

info: Crux was used by sailors in the southern hemisphere as a navigational aid to help them locate the south celestial pole.
name: Crux

info: The swan is one of two birds along with Aquila, the Eagle, which are hunted by Hercules. The swan was the pet of the Queen Cassiopeia.
name: Cygnus

info: It is believed to represent a dolphin that helped Poseidon locate the mermaid Amphitrite. As a reward, Poseidon placed it among the stars.
name: Delphinus

info: This constellation is one of southern constellations named by Johann Bayer and refers to an iridescent sea fish known as a Pompanos.
name: Dorado

info: The dragon was Laden, chosen by Hera to guard to golden apples of immortality. It was slain by Hercules in the eleventh of his twelve labors.
name: Draco

info: It represents to a carpenter's tool called a square, or a level. It is one of the constellations named by La Caille in the mid-eighteenth century.
name: Norma

info: It is represented as a long winding river starting from Orion in the north, and eventually ending in the south, at the border with Hydrus.
name: Eridanus

info: It may represent the emblem of Diane and Apollo, Cupid's arrow. Other references say that Sagittarius shot the arrow at an unknown target.
name: Sagitta

info: Named by La Caille, it represents a chemical furnace in honor of Antoine Lavoisier, who was guillotined in the French Revolution in 1794.
name: Fornax

info: This constellation was named after Castor and Pollux, two Greek heroes who were among the men Jason led on his voyages on the Argo.
name: Gemini

info: This constellation was first observed to look like a camel. The name was then changed to camelopardalis, which is Latin for giraffe.
name: Camelopardalis

info: This constellation represents the larger of Orion's two hunting dogs. It is the home of Sirius, the brightest star in the night sky.
name: Canis Major

info: This is the best-known constellation. The shape of the bear can be seen clearly, with the handle of the dipper making up the bear's tail.
name: Ursa Major

info: It was named by Johann Bayer in 1603 and represents the crane, which was the symbol for the office of astronomer in ancient Egypt.
name: Grus

info: The constellation was named after Hercules, the son of Zeus, who defeated the Nemean Lion, Leo, and the many-headed beast called Hydra.
name: Hercules

info: Invented by La Caille, it was originally called Horologium Oscillitorium to honor Christian Huygens, the inventor of the pendulum clock.
name: Horologium

info: Hydra was a giant beast with the body of a dog and a hundred snake-like heads. It was slain by Hercules on the second of his twelve labors.
name: Hydra

info: It is one of twelve constellations named by Johann Bayer. It is often confused with Hydra, the large constellation further north.
name: Hydrus

info: Johann Bayer chose this name to honor the Native Americans that European travelers had encountered during their travels and expeditions.
name: Indus

info: Lacerta, the lizard, is one of seven constellations created by the Polish astronomer Johannes Hevelius in the seventeenth century.
name: Lacerta

info: Monoceros is a faint constellation associated in older times with the shape of a unicorn. The faint stars make its shape difficult to discern.
name: Monoceros

info: The hare is being hunted by Orion and his two hunting dogs, Canis Major and Canis Minor. Do not confuse Lepus with Lupus, the wolf.
name: Lepus

info: It was named after the Nemean lion, strangled by Hercules on the first of his twelve labors after the hero unsuccessfully tried to reason with it.
name: Leo

info: Its shape is not very obvious. Seen as an unidentified animal by the Greeks and Romans, it has only recently been referred to as a wolf.
name: Lupus

info: Being composed of extremely faint stars, it was said that anyone who studied these stars should have eyes like a lynx, hence the name.
name: Lynx

info: The Lyre was invented by Hermes as a gift to his half-brother Apollo, who gave it to Orpheus, the musician of the Argonauts.
name: Lyra

info: Originally named "Antlia Pneumatica and Machine Pneumatique", it commemorates the invention of the air pump by Robert Boyle.
name: Antlia

info: Named by La Caille to honor the invention of the microscope, it is one of several constellations named after scientific instruments.
name: Microscopium

info: This constellation was named for its shape, resembling that of a housefly. Johann Bayer originally called it Apis, which meant "the Fly Bee".
name: Musca

info: Octans is a circumpolar and is visible all night long. It contains the South Celestial Pole and was named after the octant, a navigational tool.
name: Octans

info: This constellation invented by Bayer represents the bird of paradise also known at the time as Apus Indica, with the meaning of "Bird of India".
name: Apus

info: It was named after the physician Aesculapius. Serpents were always associated with physicians, making them the symbol for medicine.
name: Ophiuchus

info: After Orion was killed by Scorpius, the scorpion, the god put them at opposite sides of the sky so that he could never be hurt by it again.
name: Orion

info: When the ancient giant Argus was killed by Hermes, the goddess Hera decided to put all its hundred eyes on the tail of her peacock.
name: Pavo

info: Pegasus is the son of Neptune and Medusa who eventually became the thundering winged horse of Zeus and the carrier of his lightning bolts.
name: Pegasus

info: This is one of the constellations named by La Caille during his trip to the Cape of Good Hope. Its shape resembles that of a painting easel.
name: Pictor

info: It was named after the legendary hero who rescued Andromeda from the monster, Cetus. They fell in love and were both placed in the stars.
name: Perseus

info: Equuleus is an old constellation identified by Ptolemy. It may represent Cerleris, the brother of Pegasus, given to Castor by Mercury.
name: Equuleus

info: This constellation represents the smaller of Orion's two hunting dogs. It got its name from the fact that is rises before Sirius, the dog star.
name: Canis Minor

info: Located just above Leo, it doesn't really resemble a lion at all. It was introduced by Johannes Hevelius in the catalog released after his death.
name: Leo Minor

info: The constellation actually resembles a flying gull as seen face-on. Home of the Dumbbell Nebula, it resembles a dumbbell used for weight lifting.
name: Vulpecula

info: This constellation is famous for the Little Dipper and for Polaris, the North Star, which is located at the tip of the dipper's handle.
name: Ursa Minor

info: This constellation represents the mythological bird that would be consumed by fire and then emerge from the flames reborn.
name: Phoenix

info: Pisces represents a pair of fish facing in opposite directions, but swimming together and connected at the tail by a common star.
name: Pisces

info: This constellation may have been the original Pisces. It represents a fish lying on its back drinking the waters from the jar of Aquarius.
name: Piscis Austrinus

info: This constellation was originally named Piscis Volansis by Johann Bayer. It resembles a flying fish as seen from the side.
name: Volans

info: This large southern constellation represents the stern, or poop deck, of Argo Navis, the ship of Jason and the Argonauts.
name: Puppis

info: This constellation resembles a gridwork of lines in the eyepiece of an optical instrument, also known as a reticle. It is also described as a net.
name: Reticulum

info: Sagittarius, half-man half-beast creature, stands with his bow aimed at the heart of Scorpius. It marks the direction of the center of our galaxy.
name: Sagittarius

info: Scorpius was sent by a jealous Artemis to slay Orion. It still chases him, but never catches him because it rises after Orion has set.
name: Scorpius

info: The Serpent is split into its head and tail by the constellation Ophiuchus, the Serpent Bearer, who holds the serpent in his hands.
name: Serpens Caput

info: The Serpent is split into its head and tail by the constellation Ophiuchus, the Serpent Bearer, who holds the serpent in his hands.
name: Serpens Cauda

info: The Sextant was named by Johannes Hevelius in honor of the instrument he used successfully to make stellar measurements from 1658 to 1679.
name: Sextans

info: This constellation was originally named "Mons Mensa", after the mountain with a flattened top near La Caille's observatory in Cape Town.
name: Mensa

info: It is believed to represent the story of Europa, daughter of Agenor King of Phoenica, and a majestic white bull, which was Zeus in disguise.
name: Taurus

info: Telescopium was named by La Caille in the mid-eighteenth century after one of the most important pieces of equipment in astronomy.
name: Telescopium

info: Tucana is one of three exotic birds, which are grouped around the South Pole. The other two are Pavo (the Peacock) and Apus (Bird of Paradise).
name: Tucana

info: This is one of the constellations first drawn by Ptolemy. In ancient times, its distinctive shape of three stars was called Deltoton.
name: Triangulum

info: It can easily be recognized by its shape. Its three brightest stars have been called the "Three Patriarchs", Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.
name: Triangulum Australe

info: Aquarius represents a man pouring water from a bucket. In Greek mythology, Aquarius was Ganymede, the cupbearer to the gods.
name: Aquarius

info: Often depicted as a maiden, Virgo is the constellation that announces the harvest, since the Sun passes through it in mid-September.
name: Virgo

info: Vela represents the sails of Argo Navis, a larger constellation which was split up into four smaller ones: Carina, Puppis, Pyxis, and Vela.
name: Vela
